name: The Rogue Immaculate: Rogue19 / Cleric20 / Shadowdancer1
author: grizzled_dwarflord

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content:
Sometimes you just want the best of all possible worlds….
 ... to dodge like a Rogue
... to buff like a Cleric
... and then fade into the shadows.

The Rogue Immaculate
 
Classes: Rogue19/Cleric20/Shadowdancer1
Race: Halfling
Alignment: Any
Playable: 1-40 Low to Mid Magic PvE
Deity: Brandobaris
 
Attributes
Str10
Int14
Wis15 (19)
Dex18 (28)
Con10
Chr8
 
Level Guide
1 Rogue 1, Toughness
2 Cleric 1, Travel & Trickery Domains
3 Cleric 2, Weapon Finesse
4 Cleric 3, Wis16
5 Cleric 4
6 Cleric 5, Extend Spell
7 Cleric 6
8 Rogue 2, Wis17
9 Cleric 7, Craft Wand
10 Cleric 8
11 Cleric 9
12 Cleric 10, Weapon Focus: Mace, Wis18
13 Rogue 3
14 Cleric 11
15 Cleric 12, Dodge
16 Cleric 13, Dex19
17 Cleric 14
18 Rogue 4, Mobility
19 Cleric 15
20 Cleric 16, Dex20
21 Shadowdancer 1, Great Dex I, (HiPS)
22 Rogue 5
23 Rogue 6
24 Rogue 7, Great Dex II, Dex23
25 Rogue 8
26 Rogue 9
27 Rogue 10, Improved Evasion, Great Dex III
28 Rogue 11, Dex25
29 Rogue 12
30 Rogue 13, Defensive Roll, Epic Dodge
31 Rogue 14
32 Rogue 15, Wis19
33 Cleric 17, Epic Weapon Focus: Mace
34 Cleric 18
35 Cleric 19
36 Rogue 16, Crippling Strike, Great Dex IV, Dex27
37 Rogue 17
38 Rogue 18
39 Cleric 20, Epic Prowess
40 Rogue 19, Improved Sneak Attack*, Dex28
 
*you may opt for Slippery Mind or Epic Skill Focus instead
 
Combat Vitals
Unbuffed Melee AB: 39/34/29
Unbuffed Ranged AB: 35
Buffed AB Schedule: 65/60/55/65/65
(The above attack schedule is based on Divine Power, Divine Favor, Greater Magic Weapon, Bless, Aid, Prayer, Battle Tide, and +12 to Dex through items, and Haste.  Note that 3 attacks come at Full AB)
Sneak Attack: 11d6
Naked AC: 30 (with mundane shield)
HP: 322
 

Skills: 308
Craft Weapon: 5 (7) *needed for Wand Crafting
Hide: 43 (52)
Move Silently: 43 (54)
UMD: 31 (30)
Tumble: 40
Concentration: 42
Spellcraft: 38 (40)
Open Lock: 10 (19)
Set Trap: 25 (36)
Disable Trap: 30 (34)
Search: 2 (4)


Saves                   vs. Spells
Fort:      22            (30)
Reflex:  29            (37)
Will:       26            (34)
 
Special Abilities
  • Self Buffing Epic Dodger
  • Divine Trickery for insta-buff to Rogue Skills
  • Improved Invis
  • Haste
  • Craft Wand for ultimate utility
  • Divine Power (Extended) to maximize AB Schedule
  • Hide in Plain Sight
  • 11d6 Sneak Dice + Crippling Strike
  • Great Skill Set
  • Can still cast Level 9 Summons for distractions
  • Can deal with just about every situation
  • Wide Array of Damage Dealing
 
Weaknesses
  • Still susceptible to Greater Dispelling
  • Fort Save, while decent vs. Spells, is not dev crit-resistant
  • Low Hit Points
  • Not a DC Cleric, so don’t expect to win Implosion Battles.
  • Lacks that knock out punch (but wins by not fighting fair)
  • As a melee hybrid, lacks Blindfighting (but can mitigate this with Invis Purge).
  • No Discipline, so know thy enemy
 
Builder’s Commentary
This is bit of weird cat, but in play testing he performs surprisingly well (in playtesting on a PW, I leveled up lightning quick).  There’s not much that a Cleric Rogue can’t do.  He’s great defensively (HiPS, Epic Dodge, an unending supply of Improved Invis, nice AC, Improved Evasion, Aura vs. Alignment), and he has just enough offense that the enemy can’t go to sleep on you – 11d6 sneak, Hastes, Harms, Summons, Crippling Strike, and the ability to buff his AB to the hilt:  Divine Power for +5 and extra attack, Divine Favor for +5, Bless, Aid, Bulls, Greater Magic Weapon, Darkfire.
 
Further, his Rogue skill set makes him able to deal with disabling most traps, setting traps, opening locks, etc., all of which he can augment with his Divine Trickery when needed for that extra boost.  He can further augment with Find/Remove Traps.  With over 300 skill points, there’s just enough flexibility to customize for your own environments.
 
His saves are better than typical melee builds, but Fort is lacking against non-spells.
 
Travel & Trickery are chosen for Haste and the Invis Line of spells, all of which can be extended and/or crafted into Wands.  These two domains provide for the best mix of both offense and defense for combat, in my opinion.  However, there is some value in choosing Plant & Animal for Cat’s Grace (or War) access and Improved Summons.
 
Mace was chosen in this build for bludgeoning and it can still be finessed while wearing a large shield.
 
Play Style
Pre-epic you’re pretty much like any other hybrid Cleric melee type, augmented by your Rogue Skill set.  With a 10 Strength and 18 Dexterity, you’ll want to start with Chain Shirt and Small Shield and rely on your Summons and Buffs, supplemented by Ranged Sneaks, to make your way.  As you begin to mature your Cleric spell set, you’ll eventually be able to go with lighter armor or Robes.  In epic your Rogue talents begin to mature, and you don’t gain Epic Dodge until Level 30 (just 3 levels shy from the minimum level requirement).  In Epic you begin to use your HiPS talents, and become more of an offensive force. 
 
Your preferred melee talent is Turning on Divine Power and Haste and, while buffed to the max, use HiPS to lay waste to your enemy.
 
Preferred Spell Sets
1st: Bless, Shield of Faith, Prot from Alignment, Divine Favor
2nd: Bulls Strength, Endurance, Aid, Extended Divine Favor
3rd: Magic Vestment (x2), Prot. From Elements, Darkfire, Prayer
4th: Greater Magic Weapon, Divine Power
5th: Extended Divine Power, Haste, Improved Invis, Spell Resistance
6th: Extended Haste, Harm, Heal, Greater Sanc, Battletide
7th: Summon VII, Extended Greater Sanc, Word of faith
8th: Summon VIII, Aura vs Alignmnent
9th: Summon IX, Extended Aura
 
Wand Crafting: Protection from Elements, Invisibility, Improved Invis, Haste (Level 10 version), Summons I-IV, Hammer of the Gods, GMW (15), Bulls and Endurance (10 or 15), Find Traps, Cure Critical, Inflict Critical.  Mileage Varies
 
Related Builds:  Only one that really attempts at what the Rogue Immaculate does, and it’s too min/maxed and not nearly as playable (and loses out on 9th level spells). The Buffed Rogue 
 
The Hermit:  Lower AB and doesn’t get Epic Dodge until Level 39

Rogue Immaculate variant: If desiring something more dispel-resistant, go Rogue16/Cleric23/SD1.  Your final changes will come near the end.  You'll lose 3d6 sneak and 18 skill points, but you'll be a bit more Dispel resistant and gain an Epic Cleric Bonus Feat (Epic Mummy would be ideal).

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Hi GDL
Great to read this build and the playtesting you've done on

It looks really nice, halfling rogue cleric SD, epic dodge cripping strike, piles of skill points and a great AB for a BAB 25 build which will be useful in both melee and ranged forms

I am keen to try out a dex cleric rogue at some stage, if or when I play this I would be quite tempted to drop the starting STR just a tad to 8 and put CON to 12 to fit in Blind Fight in exchange for toughness, I know low STR builds are pretty annoying to play due to encumberance, but with the high Dex score I'm hoping I can graduate pretty quickly from chain shirt to leather/padded to robes. I guess the downside would be if you get dispelled then your damage output will suffer a little

I suspect you can live without improved knockdown with HiPS in the build to do plenty of sneak attack damage but I'm not 100% sure, I'm pretty sure you had enough tools in the kit to manage without it?

Anyway thanks for posting this up and happy holidays

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
I love new builds and this is not an exception. Not having 24 In the primary casting class is always a hard one for me personally to build to but this is one I would try without it ... well done.

Incidentally, I wanted to thank you mate. When I was looking for a new game to play a few years back i was looking at briefly replaying some NwN (one of my favourite games from yesteryear). I was looking at custom modules when I stumbled on the NwN nights multiplayer servers. I started on Blackstone Keep with a build I found after scrounging around the Internet for hours ... The Charnel Lord. I have been to many worlds and experienced many builds since then, but he is still one of my favourite builds and sure beats the heck out of my straight Paladin from the original releases!

So, my thanks for sucking me back into this wonderful mess called NwN :). My “brief” replay is going on 3 years now :). Also, I told my wife it was all your fault ... so there is that ...


Sent from my iPad using Tapatalk

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: I would be sorely tempted to take Blind Fight instead of Toughness despite the low health.

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content:
Orion2019 wrote:
Dec 28, 2019
I suspect you can live without improved knockdown with HiPS in the build to do plenty of sneak attack damage but I'm not 100% sure, I'm pretty sure you had enough tools in the kit to manage without it?
Yes, there are plenty of ways to live without IKD.  Sneak Attacks don't mature until Epic Levels, so by the time you get it you'll already have HiPS.  But you also have Invis and Improved Invis, and by crafting Wands of these spells it's effectively a poor man's HiPS.  And then you still have a wide variety of Summons to allow you to conduct Flanking Sneaks.  And then there is good ole fashion corner sneaking, or dropping some Hammer of the Gods on the weak-willed and grabbing sneaks that way.  Yes, plenty of ways to launch and land sneaks.  

@Zanithar , sorry about the Charnel Lord.  I have a halfling and half-orc variant of the same concept, called the Hin Abomination and the Lich Lord respectively, but I never bothered posting them.  As for Dispel Resistance, I was tempted for the 23 Cleric variant, but I like having more Rogue Levels at the end of the day.  I added a note at the end about doing that though: " Rogue16/Cleric23/SD1:  Your final changes will come near the end.  You'll lose 3d6 sneak and 18 skill points, but you'll be a bit more Dispel resistant and gain an Epic Cleric Bonus Feat (Epic Mummy would be ideal)."

@Empyre65 : Yes, it is tempting.  My thought on that is this:  Blindfighting is more situational for combat scenarios.  And it depends on the source of your enemies' concealment -- Is it innate, like in a wraith, or is it manufactured, as in a spell.  If the latter, what is their caster level?  Can it be something that your Cleric powers can dispel with Dispel or Greater Dispelling.  Obviously Invis Purge will strip Concealment that is manufactured (even the Assassin's Improved Invis).  Of course, this will also strip your own.  Hit Points, on the other hand, or finite in the nature, and the more you have the more you have.  My impetus for more hit points was to provide at least a little more cushion for those direct damage spells that avoid Evasions, or those lucky crits that slip through.  I suppose the decision would rest for your environment.  If PvP, or facing many mobs with Concealment, then BF would be more of a boon than 40 hp.

Cheers my lads!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
I do enjoy a good rogue build with a juicy SA, ED and skills galore.
Cleric is a great way to secure enough damage when up against sneak immunes. Cleric also secures the best AB boost, good AC, protection from death, negative energy and so on. And you have spells to repair yourself during and after battle.
Alternatives are cleric 15 for +5 to the AB and AC buffs or cleric 24 for undispellability. But I like the middle ground you find with this build where you get level 9 spells and still retain a fair amount of rogue.
HIPS provides a great means for crowd control, either as a last resort for escape, or as an infamous way to make repeated sneak attacks.

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content:
conlaoch wrote:
Dec 30, 2019
Never having played a cleric, but having played a few rogues crosses, I thought I'd try my hand at the skill progression...

Shame leaving concentration and spell craft to last, but didn't se much way around it...
Well, skill points are fickle, and vary  by user.  I didn't really save a whole lot during my run.  I maxed out Spellcraft and Concentration pretty much at every Cleric level.  I didn't wait.  I let my Hide and Move Silently skills lag behind because Sneaks weren't a priority in pre-epic.  You're basically a full-throated cleric from 1-20.  Rogue skills have a chance to catch up in the 20-30s.

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content: Just finished (almost) this one on WoG.  My one complaint:  I leveled up too fast.  Plunged into Shield Lands at Level 12, ran all over, then sought King Ironbelly at Level 18 and was hunting Drow by Level 24.  Good times!

posts.author: kfor85
posts.content: 3rd character I got past 20 on WoG, just hit level 33 (obviously I ain't got a sliver of the kind dwarflord's skill to go hunt drow by 24) and it's been by far the most fun one up to now and his toolkit (wands, traps, sneaks, ability to generate them) really makes stuff easy. Thanks for the build!!

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
I'm curious how you are going to deal with Dragotha.

It has to be one of the really bad match-ups with your build.  A Dracolich of Epic proportions, able to easily dispel (and breach) your spells (due to low spellcaster level), is hard to hit (even with a 65 AB which, let us face it, will not survive the dispels, anyway) AND has too much SR to be Healed to death.  And with a high AB will hit you for massive damage, even with DR.  No HiPS due to vanilla TS, either.

And definitely bring a Wand of Lesser Dispel with you (UMD ftw!!!) - otherwise the Shields will get you.

Don't get Bigby-ed.

posts.author: kfor85
posts.content: I gave him a visit just before I posted after killing maggris. Obviously I dirtnapped due to not being prepared enough, hitting him wasn't the problem, dispels surely were but I think I can bait his dispels with summons, buff and bash him the next time I'm around. Or try some of the epic traps I found in his neighbourhood

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Trapping might be the way to go.

Especially how Draggy is now, he's no pushover like he used to be.  Now that his Summons problem has been dealt with, and his minions now spawn, that makes Draggy a tick harder.  A high level Cleric can deal with him, but one with only 20 levels is going to be struggling.  Too much SR - bring some Mord scrolls (his SR got majorly buffed).

I'm serious here, Dragotha really has like all the weaknesses of the build as strengths.  Undead (no crits, no sneaks, no crippling strike, either), Ancient Dragon gives excellent DR (gonna need a +6 mace here), a whole slew of DR for elements as well.  Divine damage will work well, that's a given.

Please post back when you have succeeded, I'd like to hear the story.

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content: I never posted my alternate version, though one of us may have alluded to it earlier in the thread.  Basically the same as this except I siphoned 3 levels from Rogue and added it to Cleric for to make her a bit more dispel-resistant. Like you, I was starting to weary of the Dispel spam by the Drow in that certain place in the Underdark.  If I weren't a solo-artist I would probably keep it as-is for a well balanced party tends to cover one's blemishes, so to speak.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content: Adjusting for environment gets an A+ from me!

posts.author: kfor85
posts.content:
So I'll probably move level 16 of rogue to 37 to max tumble and get the rest levels remaining as cleric.
Thanks for the great advice, people!
